BE11:21am

hi hi
11:21 am
BE11:21am

£15m of pre-tax cost synergies have been highlighted, with 50% expected by FY19, with £13m of one-off cash costs to achieve this. In addition, a £7m incremental EBITDA benefit is expected from converting at least 15 current TRG Leisure brands to Wagamama by Dec-20. Elsewhere, acquisition rationale focuses on accelerating growth potential, including further roll-out (potential for 40-60 additional restaurants in the UK), the opportunity in delivery, international expansion in particular within concessions, and opportunity in convenience.

BE11:22am

Wagamama is a pan-Asia restaurant chain with 138 directly-operated sites in the UK & US, along with 58 franchised units in Europe, the Middle East and New Zealand. The group has delivered a strong recent operating performance, with on average c.9.6% LFL growth over the last four years. However, we would note that whilst top-line progress remains strong reported £306.7m of revenues in FY18 (+15% y-o-y), profit growth was limited with EBITDA of £43m (up +1% y-o-y), most likely the result of the significant headwinds facing UK restaurant chains.

RAFI Mito!
#REF! I very much do want good Ramen for breakfast... but my pickiness over that dish precludes wagamama (who are ok otherwise)
BE11:22am

The acquisition of Wagamama is undoubtedly transformational, and given the existing growth has delivered -2.2% LFL YTD (42 weeks), and just 1.4% LFL for the last 14 weeks despite easy comps and a strong concessions and pubs business, issues undoubtedly remain with the Leisure brands. Whilst Wagamama is a strong brand with good recent track record, question marks remain for us over the cost backdrop and supply environment in casual dining, and the level of debt being taken on considering high levels of lease obligations.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Okay, so leases.

BE11:23am

They're short. Very.

11:24 am

• Wagamama is a good brand, but its EBITDA was flat in 2018, a period in which its EBITDA margin fell by 200bps. Also, according to Restaurant
Group’s management, Wagamama only has the potential for a further 40-
60 sites vs 138 in the UK at present.

• Most importantly, despite the likely dilution of the rights issue, the deal leaves the company on net debt/EBITDA of 2.2x post all synergy benefits for an estate that will be over 90% short-leasehold. We expect net debt/EBITDAR to be close to 8x, higher than that of the pub companies.

Whilst Wagamama is a strong brand with good recent track record, question marks remain for us over the cost backdrop and supply environment in casual dining, and the level of debt being taken on considering high levels of lease obligations.

We're flattish following a stupid day in the States. Nearly a 1k swing, firstly on the idea that China would halve its tax on wee-engined cars and then on tariff noise.

Rather than making up a narrative to pin on that, let's turn back domestic.

BE11:33am

WH Smith requested. US acquisition.

11:33 am
WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,847, up 113 (+6.52%), High: 1,862, Low: 1,760, Volume: 355.20k
hornblower @ 1st Lt - say what you really think
BE11:33am

Buying one of those airport chains that sell USB cables and adapter plugs at a 1000% markup.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @hornblower - I did.
Random McHiggins And travel pillows
BE11:34am

Again, it's expensive. But if you believe WH Smith has something new to offer US trapped-customer retail, it's strategically sensible.

Foundy @ 1st Lt - not to generalize tho...
11:34 am
BE11:35am

Here's Barclays' bullet points.

BE11:35am

· InMotion is a pure play travel operator, entirely exposed to the US market, operating 114 stores across 43 US airports, including 22 of the top 25 busiest US airports.

· The company specialises in digital accessories such as headphones, mobile power, and portable speakers.

· LFL sales growth has been strong, with LFL sales growth of 13% in calendar year 2018, vs LFLs of 12% in calendar year 2017.

· EBITDA is expected to be $23m in FY18 (to December), although this falls to $20m after $3m of pre-tax profit paid to minority partners (mandatory under many US lease contracts), and it is the $20m on which the company has reported its EV/EBITDA (9.9x).

· The deal will be debt financed, using a 4-year £200m term loan, at a margin of LIBOR +100bps.

BE11:35am

This transaction gives the company a number of benefits:

· WH Smith increases its exposure into Travel, from c65% of EBIT currently (depreciation not in the release, so we cannot yet calculate the future EBIT split). Concerns over UK High Street exposure should continue to subside as Travel exposure becomes larger.

· It potentially unlocks the US market for the company, where it currently has no sites, and landlord relationships could be unlocked to roll out the company’s existing offering into US airports.

· The company can use the InMotion offering in other sites outside the US, where it has already built a large International Travel business outside the UK (286 sites open at FY18), but with a different product offering.

· The deal is said to be EPS accretive in the first full year post completion, ROIC will exceed WACC by year 3, and it will be FCF accretive. There is no change to the £50m buyback announced, and there is no change to the dividend policy.

· PF Debt/EBITDA post completion of this deal is expected to move to 0.8x, which we consider comfortable.

Our main concern with a deal in this sector would be paying a premium for an operator that has relatively short concession periods, so better understanding landlord relationships and visibility over any key contract renewals would be obvious questions for management. The fact that InMotion is the market leader in North America in the digital market is encouraging.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @foundy - What I say is almost a FACT. People don't like reality do they.
Excel Developer Domestic? Sure GBP in a downward channel against both USD and EUR since 10th Oct
11:36 am
BE11:36am

As we've said many times, it's difficult to see how consumers benefit from the airport concession auction system whereby a company pays a lot for its exclusive or quasi-exclusive pitch then gouges customers to claw back the cash.

Waterloo GE big miss
Random McHiggins Its the only place that kind of retail can go in my opinion - if you need it right now you have to pay big
BE11:38am

RBC incoming.

Random McHiggins Maybe they can get the TSA to bring in some more bans
BE11:38am

1. Entry into the large $10bn US travel retail market, of which c.$3bn comes from News, Gift and Specialty Retail categories. Inmotion has 114
stores across 43 airports and is present in 22 of the 25 busiest airports in the US. It should generate revenue of c.£130mn this year with EBITDA of c.£16mn post minority interests. Recent LFL sales have been low double-digit up with broadly stable margins.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

2. A platform to launch the WH Smith's Travel format in the US using Inmotion's market knowledge, infrastructure and strong landlord relationships. The travel essentials category there is currently dominated by Hudson News (owned by Dufry) but over time we expect WH Smith to gain share on account of its superior sales densities and category mix management.

BE11:39am

3. WH Smith can export the Inmotion brand into its other airports. This should be complementary to WH Smith's existing strategy of developing
specialist formats to broaden its appeal to landlords, such as its techexpress by WH Smith format.

BE11:39am

In addition to news of the acquisition, WH Smith has confirmed it has made a strong start to the current financial year with total Travel sales up 10% yoy for the first 8 weeks, driven by International space, including LFL sales +4% yoy, and High Street LFL sales -2% yoy. Passenger numbers have been in line with recent trends, with WH Smith benefitting from higher spend per passenger at its refurbished larger airport stores.
Overall we think WH Smith's statement today should reassure the market, particularly as it now takes the proportion of EBIT generated by Travel Retail from just over 60% to closer to 70%, with High Street becoming less and less of the pie.
The market was somewhat spooked by the plans for High Street restructuring announced at the FY results earlier this month, but we think this deal should give the Travel retail story renewed impetus. Subject to execution, we think the multiple paid would look full for a mature electricals retailer but looks very reasonable for what is a pureplay Travel growth retailer.
WH Smith trades at c.15x CY19 P/E and offers a 3% dividend yield and share buyback of up to £50mn/year which we think is attractive versus higher rated Travel retail pureplay peers which trade at multiples in the low to high 20s.

rwl SMWH seems to buck the retail trend.
11:40 am
BE11:40am

And Citi, since we're here.

BE11:40am

There have been a number of small strategic acquisitions over the last few years such as in Australia but this offers a launch pad into the biggest market. It is almost 25 years since WH Smith pulled out of the US market and we believe they have been looking for an attractive way to re-enter the market. The InMotion acquisition gives strong relationships with the US airports (mostly municipal authority run) and with the technology suppliers. This gives three avenues for growth: 1) Extending the In Motion brand into more US airports, 2) Expanding the InMotion offering into other global markets where WH Smith has a presence and 3) Taking the WH Smith format into the existing InMotion US airports.

Shinshin Surprised the airports don't run their own basic distress purchase stores - water, cables, books, etc. They're very happy to gouge on parking and their other monopoly services.

11:48 am

Merrill are fine with that.

BE11:49am

RB reported its Q3 trading update earlier today. Q3 LFL came in at +2%, significantly below our and consensus forecast of +4%. The miss was entirely attributable to an unexpected LFL decline in the Infant Formula and Child Nutrition division where sales contracted by -6% (vs. +9% in Q2); this was reflective of a "temporary manufacturing disruption" at the IFCN division European plant that shaved off GBP70m of the group's revenues in Q3. In other words, adjusted for this adverse effect, IFCN would have expanded by c. 4% on a LFL basis in the quarter. Both HyHo and Rest of Health reported 4% LFL in Q3 ahead of consensus expectations of 3.4% and 3.8% respectively. Despite this softer than anticipated Q3 performance, RB confirmed its FY18 outlook of LFL at the upper end of the 2-3% range and constant currency sales growth in the 14-15% range {in-line with consensus of 3.1% and +14.8% respectively}. Reiterate BUY and PO of GBp8,000.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If the executives had been a little more patient they wouldn't be messing with this baby nonsense and they would have had excellent opportunity with consumer health care sales - potentially - at GSK and Pfizer. Personal incentives rushed the business plan IMO.

As are Morgan Stanley, after a fashion.

Flaneur @Ir - well, if one assumes that applications will continue to grow in complexity, and they are processed in the cloud, its unlikely taht processing power will be needed locally (ie on a phone).
11:49 am
BE11:50am

Q3 LFL 2% vs cons 4.0%. Reckitt’s Q3 this morning is overshadowed by another negative one-off (from manufacturing disruption in their Dutch Babyfood plant). Whilst we do not see this as a big consensus earnings driver, in the context of multiple one-offs over the last 2 years, it could have an adverse impact on sentiment and drive an overreaction in the stock price. We would view a move down of 3-5% as a significant buying opportunity, because we believe that there are clear signs (outside the manufacturing disruption) that Reckitt is gaining momentum across its business with the RB 2.0 strategy starting to gain real traction.

irish hedge fund guy @viking1, Fraport is priced reasonably and operates Frankfurt, Greek concessions, Brazil, and Turkish airports. 10x EDITDA and growing nicely. Interesting observation that increased security lines hurting shopping at Frankfurt airport.
BE11:50am

While we view this new one-off as a clear setback on the path towards consistent delivery, we remain committed to our bullish RB 2020 thesis. We continue to consistently outline three potential sources of upside: i) turnaround (RB/Mead), ii) cash/valuation and iii) strategic optionality. We now factor in potential higher investments in supply chain for Mead and lower our margin assumptions by c.150bps and cut earnings estimates by 2-3% over 2018-20e. We cut our price target to £85 (vs £88) largely reflecting the earnings cut.

hornblower I wonder where the RTN rights are underwritten, not pricing until end November, a long time with current market jitters

11:58 am

BE11:58am

As explained in a very irritated JPM earnings preview.

Excel Developer @BE: throwing shade on FT writer Ed Crooks.
BE11:59am

Given EPS has almost no connection to fundamental reality, if there is one number that defines the debate it’s FCF, and here, given the last official communication was

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

....less than $6 B, we have been basing our analysis around an expectation of ~$5 B, and anything lower would mean our math from the last several weeks has been too generous. To be clear, we don’t really care much about some randomly defined “consensus” for trading purposes. It’s about what the run rate means for the math and a FCF number of $4 B would mean negative FCF at remainco GE, and another downward revision to what we presented in recent notes where we highlight ~$100 B in net liabilities at the enterprise. The flaw we see is that many are using the separate, discretionary financial statements to define the value of a GECS business that was set up, and used opaque intercompany transactions, to help Industrial FCF to be pulled forward enabled by access to cheap credit that is no longer available (a notion supported by comments from several former employees as disclosed in recent class actions, publicly available), and, therefore, enterprise analysis becomes more relevant – one door in, one door out on cash, which we have shown is negative by $4 B including the dividend.

BE12:01pm

Divi cut negative from the perspective of the passives but don't expect even the severe cut seen today to help the balance sheet that much. JPM said.

BE12:02pm

to be clear, we do not think GE is priced for liquidity issues (even though they are likely drawing their revolver), and so while a dividend cut would help future forecasts for capitalization, even excluding the dividend the enterprise is generating no FCF; so, a cut is not the positive silver bullet Bulls are making it out to be, and does not automatically turn GE into DHR.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

They also called shennanigans.

BE12:02pm

we believe Sell Side Bulls are setting an artificially low level for expectations with some calling $4 B and a removal of the dividend as “in line”, and the only thing that matters is what investors can “believe” can be the run rate on earnings a few years forward (even though the current construct on earnings is not credible), with many still noting $1 in EPS as a centerpiece of the thesis.
